Expectation1: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation1: Several users report intermittent errors that disrupt normal usage
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A heat advisory is issued for the day and an elderly neighbor on the floor lives alone.
Story: I was deep into debugging a stubborn error that users kept reporting—something about the app freezing at random. My inbox was filling up with urgent messages from QA, and my manager had just pinged me, asking for a fix before the end of the day. The pressure was mounting; I knew how much our users depended on the app, and I didn’t want to let the team down. Just as I was about to run another test, my phone buzzed with a city alert: a severe heat advisory had been issued. I remembered Mrs. Lee, my elderly neighbor who lived alone on my floor. She rarely left her apartment and didn’t have air conditioning. The city’s message urged everyone to check on vulnerable neighbors. I felt a knot tighten in my stomach. I wanted to be a responsible citizen, to make sure Mrs. Lee was safe, but I also couldn’t ignore the demands piling up at work. My mind raced, torn between the expectation to fix the app and the responsibility to help someone in need right next door.
